If you can help us, you would have our gratitude, and we would be willing to share some of our space travel technology with you as well as tell you some of what we know of your ancestors.

The rescue team we sent to Horazon has made the most remarkable discovery. As they dug deep into the planet, attempting to create a stable shaft by which the trapped miners could be rescued, they discovered the ancient remnants of a crashed ship. It soon became apparent this ship, originally of alien design, was modified by Teekan engineers. Preliminary analysis suggests it comes from the time of the Shakturi conflict.
Unfortunately, we face a conundrum. The remains of the ship were discovered lodged in a position that is now structurally unsound. While we could stabilize the site, with our limited resources, the process will take several days, thus delaying the rescue of the miners. We must choose which operation to prioritize.

Teekans, had you been willing to help us, we would have embraced you as alien siblings. Instead, you turn your back on us in our hour of need. The politician trapped in the mine has been vital to maintaining unity among the various factions on our world. The loss of this unifier will plunge our world into chaos. I have no doubt a new politician will rise, one who will seek to unite our people against a common enemy. That enemy will most likely be you, Teekans. You will regret your decision.
You refused to help us

Though it is a painful decision, we have decided we must help the miners and set aside our curiosity about the past. Our engineers drilled through the rock and safely penetrated the chamber in which the miners were trapped. The beings of Horazon are effusive in their gratitude, and they make promises of friendship and have already begun to present some of their research to our scientists.
While part of the team led the miners back to the surface, the remainder turned to the ancient Teekan ship. Unfortunately, our drilling and blasting further damaged the ship. We were unable to salvage much except a severely damaged data core. At first our engineers believed they could only recover a few fragments about the Shakturi fighting something called the Freedom Alliance. Then they managed to decode one last data node. It referenced the Teekan migration to a place called the Great Teekan Refuge. The engineers were able to decode a location. They are not certain if it is this Refuge or something else, but it is certainly worth investigating.
We appreciate your assistance

So many incoming messages from Horazon demanding to know where our engineers are and why they have stopped responding to messages. Why is there no more blasting and drilling? We have spoken of technical complications, but they suspect some mischief on our part.
It is not mischief though, but curiosity. We cannot ignore this relic of our past. It took two days to stabilize the ship, and then our engineers returned to rescuing the miners. There was no way to hide the excavation site from them as they made their way to the surface, so they now know what it is that distracted us.
The diplomatic consequences may be worth the price. We have extracted some fascinating information from the fragmentary surviving portions of the ship's data storage. The Shakturi, it seems, were insectoid invaders from another galaxy. They traveled using a wormhole technology that damaged space itself, but this damage was not enough to satisfy them. They seemed determined to exterminate all life they encountered. A group of species formed a "Freedom Alliance" to counter them. Teekans, meanwhile, attempted to avoid the conflict entirely, though they traded with Freedom Alliance, the neutrals, and even those who sided with the Shakturi. We are not warriors, after all, but survivors. Many of our people relocated to a place called the Great Teekan refuge, which was believed to be safe from the fighting. In this refuge, our ancestors hoped not only to survive the war, but to hide in the aftermath. There is much trading to be done during wartime, but when the peace comes, the survivors always blame the merchants.
We have extracted coordinates to what may be that refuge, though it may be merely be another outpost. It is certainly worth investigating.
There is another, possibly more important discovery in the ship. We found the remnants of an incomplete weapon prototype, the Experimental Quantum Burst. Our ancestors were not warriors, but they clearly believed in being prepared.
The beings of Horazon remain dissatisfied. No lives were lost because of our delay, but they know we placed our own interests ahead of theirs. It may take time to improve this relationship, but everything has its cost.

We had hoped to find some evidence of the Lost Teekan Refuge, but this is most certainly something else. There is a Teekan outpost on the surface, and we detect automated defenses. In all likelihood, these were intended to protect Teekans from enemies during the Shakturi war. Scarring on the exterior of the station indicate that the station has seen battle in the distant past. Perhaps that is why it is now hostile to all who approach.
We must uncover whatever secrets are hidden within. Some Teekan scientists believe a direct military assault upon the base is the most efficient way of gaining control of the secrets within. Other suggest attempting to sabotage the base, though there is risk of damaging what lies within.

Our forces have landed on the planet surface and taken heavy fire from the base's automated defenses. Our crafty Teekan soldiers were able to get close enough to the perimeter to plant explosive and damage one of weapons batteries. This enabled the ground troops to advance, enter the base, and disable the defensive systems.
Once they gained access, it was only a matter of accessing the bases databanks, which are much decayed but in better condition than we had hoped. We have reviewed accounts of a great Teekan migration traversing the galaxy as they tried to stay ahead of the Shakturi invaders. Entire worlds, entire species, fell before the might of this brutal hivemind. The Teekans attempted to stay ahead of the Shakturi advance, abandoning the Teekan homeworld. They sustained themselves with salvage, which they repurposed, recycled, or sold as best suited their needs. Indeed, the debris field surround this world seems to be the remnants of a massive Teekan salvage operation.
Now we know why this station was attacked long ago. Much like today, ancient Teekans preferred to remain neutral, to trade with all customers, but much of the salvage here is of Mortalen origin. The ancient Teekans were reluctant to take Mortalen salvage, not wanting to worsen relations with an already hostile empire, but it seems that resources became scarce when various insectoid species suddenly refused to trade or even communicate. Teekans had no choice but to take what they could find to make up for the shortfall. Records suggest that the Mortalens responded to Teekans salvaging their wrecks by assaulting this base. Our ancestors attempted to negotiate with them, but the outcome is not recorded here.
The databanks also reveal two more locations. They are unlikely to be the Great Teekan Refuge, but perhaps something there will provide the clues we seek.

After careful study of the base, our scientists believe they are ready to attempt to shut down its defensive operations. There is some risk. There are subroutines designed to erase the memory core should infiltration be detected. Ancient Teekan thinking is much like modern Teekan thinking, however, and it should be possible to find exploits in the system that would be invisible to alien minds.

The system has detected our presence! We were able to shut down its operations, but not before it began to dump its data core. It began by erasing technical information, no doubt in an effort to keep Teekan innovation out of enemy hands. We were able to salvage some information about ancient construction technology, however.
We have learned more about the flight of the ancient Teekans. There was a massive migration traversing the galaxy as the Teekans attempted to stay ahead of the Shakturi invaders. Entire worlds, entire species, fell before the might of this brutal hivemind. The Teekans attempted to stay ahead of the Shakturi advance, abandoning the Teekan homeworld. They sustained themselves with salvage, which they repurposed, recycled, or sold as best suited their needs. Indeed, the debris field surround this world seems to be the remnants of a great Teekan salvage operation.
Now we know why this station was attacked long ago. Much like today, ancient Teekans preferred to remain neutral, to trade with all customers, but much of the salvage here is of Mortalen origin. The ancient Teekans were reluctant to take Mortalen salvage, not wanting to worsen relations with an already hostile empire, but it seems that resources became scarce when various insectoid species suddenly refused to trade or even communicate. Teekans had no choice but to take what they could find to make up for the shortfall. Records suggest that the Mortalens responded to Teekans salvaging their wrecks by assaulting this base. Our ancestors attempted to negotiate with them, but the outcome is not recorded here.
The databanks also reveal two more locations. They are unlikely to be the Great Teekan Refuge, but perhaps something there will provide the clues we seek.

Our investigation has revealed that, long ago, this damaged station was part of a Teekan salvage operation. Much of the wreckage is of Mortalen origin, however, and much of it contains Teekan modifications. There was a battle here, and the fragmented logs indicate Mortalen forces, angered by the Teekans claiming their salvage, attacked the base. The databanks also contain some ancient technological specs, which we can use to advance our own research.

Intruders, this salvage belongs to the Airless Wanderers. We claim no soil. All of space is ours. Respect our territory, and we will have no problem with you, dirt-dweller though you may be. Encroach on our claim, and we will destroy you.
Pirates have claimed our ancient base, keeping us from learning whatever secrets can be found within. We cannot abandon the secrets of this outpost. Perhaps the pirates can be made to see reason.

Teekans, do you imagine we Airless Wanderers care only for wealth? As it happens, we care a great deal for wealth, but we also care about our honor, which you have insulted. If we meet again, it will be as combatants. I suggest you flee.
You insulted our honor

Hear us, Airless Wanderers. We are the Teekans, nomadic wanderers, much like yourselves. We do not wish to take what you have claimed, but we seek answers from our past. If you truly respect the those who wander through space, then you will negotiate with us in good faith.
Teekans, we the Airless Wanderers respect your quest. For the price of 40,000cr, we will sell you temporary access to this base. You may seek answers here and then leave, taking nothing with you.

You show wisdom, dirt-strider. We accept your payment, and you may examine this station as you wish, and then depart. Again, you may take nothing. The credits buy you the right only to examine what you find.

A small team of engineers and scientists have traveled to the base. The logs are damaged an incomplete, but this station was once one of two shipyards that served as rendezvous points for Teekans fleeing the path of the Shakturi war. There were rumors of those who stood against the Shakturi, the Freedom Alliance, developing their own secret weapon that could turn the tide of the war. As the two great powers prepared to clash, Teekans sought to be far away from the battle.
Much of this information is of no use to the pirates, of course, but by neglecting these databanks, they have missed something very valuable. In their travels, our ancestors learned the location of what they believed to be the Ancient Shakturi Arrival Point, the location where the Shakturi first entered this galaxy. There may be much to be learned by visiting this site.
We came to an honorable agreement
You made a bad deal, Teekans. Had you paid, you would have gotten what you want. Now you will get nothing, or it will cost you far more.
Negotiations went sour

Now that the Airless Wanderers have been defeated, we have gained full control of the station. The logs are damaged an incomplete, but this station was once one of two shipyards that served as rendezvous points for Teekans fleeing the path of the Shakturi war. There were rumors that the Freedom Alliance were developing their their own secret weapon that could turn the tide of the war. As the two the Freedom Alliance and the Shakturi access prepared to clash, Teekans sought to be far away from the battle.
Much of this information is of no use to the pirates, of course, but by neglecting these databanks, they have missed something very valuable. In their travels, our ancestors learned the location of what they believed to be the Ancient Shakturi Arrival Point, the location where the Shakturi first entered this galaxy. There may be much to be learned by visiting this site.

Intruders, this salvage belongs to the Airless Wanderers. We claim no soil. All of space is ours. Respect our territory, and we will have no problem with you, dirt-dweller though you may be. Encroach on our claim, and we will destroy you.

Though the station was held by pirates, it once belonged to the ancient Teekans. Most of the surviving logs speak of internal matters as they tried to survive the Shakturi was, but there is one point of particular note. They believed they located the site where the Shakturi first arrived in this galaxy. The upheaval caused by their wormhole generators would be worth investigating.

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Encounter Lost Teekan Outposts B (Non Teekan)
Investigate Lost Teekan Outposts B (Non Teekan)

GameEventAction.Description: We have discovered what appears to be a destroyed Teekan spaceport. This warrants further investigation.

The station was once dedicated to the construction of ships, no doubt in the service of providing the means for our people to flee the terrible Shakturi war. One of the last surviving logs recounts of a meeting with a Mortalen envoy. In the aftermath of a great battle, the ancient Teekans discovered a powerful Shakturi weapon, which our ancestors traded with the Mortalen in an effort to improve relations. Did the Mortalen use this weapon to defeat the Shakturi? Those answers are unlikely to be found here, but we will keep searching.

We have found something else at the Lost Teekan Outpost: a functioning android, remarkably like a biological Teekan in appearance. It calls itself the Appraiser, and it claims it was left behind in error by the fleeing Teekan exodus. It knows little of the war, but it says it can be of great service to us in matters of research and trade.
The Appraiser has shown us around the station and led us to databanks it believes we can still access. There is much we will never know, but it seems that this world served as a major coordinating hub for Teekans escaping the war. Astonishingly, we have learned that the Shakturi invaders came not from some distant corner of the galaxy, but outside the galaxy itself. More horrifically, their wormhole devices damaged space itself. They were literally destroying the galaxy they invaded. Such destructive minds are unfathomable to us.
Here, too, we have discovered what we have long sought, the location of the great Teekan refuge. We must investigate and see what we can learn.

GameEvent.Name: Encounter Lost Teekan Outposts B (Non Teekan)

GameEventAction.Description: We've discovered an ancient space station, badly damaged, and with damaged ships in orbit. This may well be worth investigating.

GameEvent.Name: Investigate Lost Teekan Outposts B (Non Teekan)

GameEventAction.Description: This station belonged to the Teekans during the time of the Shakturi war. It appears to have been dedicated to ship construction, and there are two damaged destroyers in orbit. More interesting, we've discovered a functioning android, much like a biological Teekan in appearance. It calls itself the Appraiser, and it claims it was left behind in error by the fleeing Teekan exodus. It knows little of the war, but it says it can be of great service to us in matters of research and trade.

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Investigate The Great Teekan Refuge (Non Teekan)

GameEventAction.Description:
The sadness is hard to express. A colonized world, infrastructure in place, completely abandoned. Here the ancient Teekans hoped to preserve their culture while their greatest minds hid from the war ravaging the galaxy. As the Shakturi advanced, however, the greatest military minds among the Teekans believed the location of the Refuge had been discovered. Even if it were spared Shakturi devastation, the ancients worried it would be a target after the war for those who resented Teekans trading with their enemies. With little time to prepare, the Teekans boarded their ships, launched new caravans, and sought other places to hide from the invaders.
Automated monitoring stations remained active, however, and these were in coordination with the commanders of the various Teekan caravans. These report devastation across the galaxy. The Freedom Alliance used a devastating weapon against the Shakturi, meant to interfere with their wormhole generators. Another faction, unknown to our forebears, was developing another weapon in secret, and used it at the same time as the Freedom Alliance used theirs.
The final entry speaks only of massive gravitic waves, tectonic destruction caused by the use of the two weapons. Entire caravans lost. It is impossible to calculate how many beings died as ships and worlds alike were destroyed. Only those on the few worlds that withstood the damage were able to survive, isolated though they were, along with a few caravan ships that had been in hyperspace. Terrible as these weapons were, they seem to have saved the galaxy, for the Shakturi are gone from our space.
It is a mournful irony that our ancestors fled the refuge, for it seems to have survived far better than many worlds we have visited. We have discovered marvelous artifacts here as well. Building upon what our ancestors created, we Teekans can begin anew, we can thrive and trade and grow. This will be a Great Teekan Refuge once again.

GameEvent.Name: Investigate The Great Teekan Refuge (Non Teekan)

GameEventAction.Description:
This was once the Great Teekan Refuge, a world settled by the ancient Teekans hoping to flee from the war and its aftermath. Surviving records indicate that the location of the refuge was discovered, and the Teekans were forced to flee. It is ironic, because the world sustained no damage and would be ideal for colonization by Teekans.
We have discovered marvelous Teekan artifacts here. They will no doubt serve us well.

We have uncovered the wreckage of a space vessel on {0}. It is clearly not Zenox in origin, and it appears to date from the time of the great Cataclysm. The ship's computer systems are badly damaged, and it is likely that any effort to access a portion of the memory will make the rest of the data irretrievable.
We have always prioritized knowledge above all else, but in this case, we must choose which knowledge to pursue. Do we wish to learn about the origin of this ship, where it came from and where it was going, or do we want to try to retrieve its engine schematics and learn from its ancient technology?

This ship belonged to the Haakonish, a deceptive and untrustworthy species. The logs are too fragmented for us to determine the ship's precise mission or what brought it to this system, but there are hints of a plan to use the Shakturi's own technology against them. Did the Haakonish have some mission in this system, or were they merely nearby at the time of the Cataclysm? There is mention of a Zenox military research base, and we've been able to ascertain its location. We would be wise to investigate.
Before it crashed, the Haakonish vessel was able to scan the planet. We can use that knowledge to exploit the resources here.

The computer's recoverable data makes clear that this ship belonged to the Haakonish, a deceptive and untrustworthy species. We cannot guess what the ship was doing in this part of the galaxy, or if it is a mere coincidence that it crashed in our system. Perhaps it was merely nearby at the time of the Cataclysm. Regardless, we have been able to extract partial engine schematics, and these should help our own research efforts.

On this world we have discovered the remnants of a crashed Zenox ship, dating back to the time of the Cataclysm. We believe it to have been an archive vessel, transporting data to our own world. We can only imagine how our world would have grown and thrived had this ship arrived intact. Perhaps we would have been traveling the stars for centuries already.
The ship is badly damaged. Moving it, or even interacting with it, will likely cause the corruption of any remaining files. We must choose if we wish to attempt to conserve and recover the portion of the archives dedicated to history or attempt to extract the technological data.

This vessel originated at another world, once originally intended as a colony. The minds of the ancient Zenox Technocracy soon determined that the original world was not safe from the Shakturi, and they evacuated all civilians. Instead, the world became a listening post to spy on the Shakturi and their allies. Information on those who fought the Shakturi, the Freedom Alliance which our ancestors were also involved in, was recorded as well. It is important to know what one's allies are up to and to guard against any risk of treachery.
We cannot know why this ship did not make it to its intended destination, but the final logs report massive gravitic waves. It seems likely the Cataclysm struck when the archive ship was close to reaching our world.
Now we must recover the knowledge that was lost to us. Visiting the planet from which this ship originated is a good place to start. The people on {18} rejoice at the news that we can hope to reclaim even more of our lost history.

The ships logs are lost to us, but we were able to retrieve some of the technological knowledge originally intended for our homeworld. We can use this to reach the stars sooner and begin the long process of reclaiming what we have lost.

Greetings, Zenox. We, the Liberated of the Stars, know of your kind. You are hoarders of knowledge, yes? You mine your facts, much as we mine precious resources from asteroids. You hide them away for your own use, or trade them when you can do so to your full advantage. Yes, we know you well.
Because your reputation precedes you, we know that you cannot resist the lure of new information. We have traded with other salvagers for what they claim is a databank from an ancient Freedom Alliance ship. It is said to be filled with fascinating and valuable information from the long-ago war. Perhaps you would like to know more about the ancient enemy, the Shakturi?. Their technology is said to be of great interest to researchers. Perhaps you would like to know where ancient data archives of your own ancestors are stored. It is possible such information can be found on this computer, and we will sell it to you if you can pay our price.

Zenox, you must think the Liberated of the Stars are fools. If you examine the data, then you will have the data, and you will have gotten what we sell without paying a price. No. You can accept the computer as it is, or you can declare you mistrust us and make us your enemies. For this insult the price has been raised.
GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Refuse to Buy the Computer Choice (Zenox)

GameEventAction.Description:
The Liberated of the Stars send over the computer via drone. Your data specialists begin to examine the drives, and it becomes clear at once that this is not an ancient computer, and the information it contains is nonsense, often no more than gibberish. You immediately contact the Liberated of the Stars.
"Ha ha, Zenox. We told you what information might be on the computer, we did not promise that the information was accurate. You did not ask if we knew it to be a forgery, and we saw no need to tell you. You have learned a valuable lesson today, so you cannot say your credits were not well spent."

Zenox, you would have been wise to settle for your lesson learned. Now you threaten the Liberated of the Stars? Bad move, dirt-stomper. You do not want Liberated of the Stars as your enemy, but you have angered us. Stay out of our space, and perhaps you will live.
You demanded a refund

Zenox, you have made a smart choice. You don't want Liberated of the Stars as your enemy. It is better to have us as a friend. We like your good attitude. Perhaps we may yet find ways to co-exist, sneaky dirt-dweller though you are.
You know how this works

GameEvent.Name: Refuse to Buy the Computer Choice (Zenox)

GameEventAction.Description: Zenox, you surprise us. All the galaxy knows you are knowledgeable, but now I see that you are also clever for a dirt-dweller. Yes, never buy that which you cannot examine. The computer is a forgery and worthless. We know that, and now you do too. You have earned our respect. Perhaps we might yet be friends.
We appreciate your cleverness

We've encountered an ancient space station, clearly of Zenox design. The world below shows signs of severe seismic damage.
The base is protected by defensive systems. It should not be too great of a challenge to defeat these forces, though our scientists say they can override the defensive systems. Doing so will be expensive, but we are assured success. Military ventures always present some risk.

Because we were able to preserve a portion of our ancient knowledge, we have been able to link up with the surviving computer systems on the space station. Override codes for this particular type of station are still in our possession, so we were able to power down the station and regain control.
As we feared, the station's computer systems are badly damaged, but we have been able to ascertain that this station was dedicated to monitoring and studying the military activities of the Haakonish Star Guild during the time of the Shakturi war. The Zenox Technocracy was deeply suspicious of the Haakonish, who refused to join with the Freedom Alliance against the Shakturi. More troubling, they successfully managed to keep the location of their core worlds a secret from other species. This, they believed, would enable them to play both sides against each other while they avoided the worst of the fighting. There are also references to a secret project the Haakonish had undertaken. No one knew what the nature of that project might be, but the great minds of the Zenox Technocracy were determined to learn all the Haakonish wished to keep hidden.
Our fleets are more than a match for this station's defenses. We shall capture it and unlock its secrets.

As we feared, the station's computer systems are badly damaged, but we have been able to ascertain that this station was dedicated to monitoring and studying the activities of the Haakonish Star Guild during the time of the Shakturi war. The Zenox Technocracy was deeply suspicious of the Haakonish, who refused to join with the Freedom Alliance against the Shakturi. More troubling, they had successfully managed to keep the location of their core worlds a secret from other species. This, they believed, would enable them to play both sides against each other while they avoided the worst of the fighting. There are also references to a secret project the Haakonish had undertaken. No one knew what the nature of that project might be, but the great minds of the Zenox Technocracy were determined to learn all the Haakonish wished to keep hidden.

As we feared, the station's computer systems are badly damaged, but we have been able to ascertain that this station was dedicated to monitoring and studying the activities of the Haakonish Star Guild during the time of the Shakturi war. The Zenox Technocracy was deeply suspicious of the Haakonish, who refused to join with the Freedom Alliance against the Shakturi. More troubling, they had successfully managed to keep the location of their core worlds a secret from other species. This, they believed, would enable them to play both sides against each other while they avoided the worst of the fighting. There are also references to a secret project the Haakonish had undertaken. No one knew what the nature of that project might be, but the great minds of the Zenox Technocracy were determined to learn all the Haakonish wished to keep hidden.

We are receiving a message from Pyrrho, a newly discovered world which seems remarkably advanced for survivors of the cataclysm.. "Ah, the Zenox. We have legends of you that date back to ancient times, to an era when a great conflict was said to have spread across the galaxy. Our forebears warned us against any dealings with the Zenox, whom they said were selfish and secretive, always plotting for their own ends, caring little for those who they used or destroyed. No doubt you only want to exploit us for our technological advances. We know better than to trust you or trade with you."
We have seen this before. The truth of history slowly fades into the fiction of myth. Truths are lost in the service of story. These are humans, who fought with our ancestors against the Shakturi and their allies, yet have forgotten how much they trusted and depended upon the Zenox. With the passing centuries, the recollection of Zenox as great lorekeepers becomes distorted in the Zenox as secret-keepers. It saddens us to see how they misremember the past.

These humans shame themselves and their ancestors by misrepresenting the Zenox and all we did for the galaxy during the time of the Shakturi war. Were it not for us, much that we now remember would have been lost. We preserved knowledge for the good of all. It is unacceptable for them to withhold information from us, but they must be free to exercise their own foolish beliefs. Perhaps our conduct now will give them cause to reevaluate their misconceptions.
We believe you are selfish and secretive

Our diplomats have begun a dialogue with the humans of Pyrrho. They seem willing to accept that their legends may not represent the Zenox accurately. We have presented them with true histories, showing how the Zenox were the most important faction in the war against the Shakturi, and how we sought to make certain the knowledge of all species would not be lost in the conflict.
It would undermine our diplomatic efforts, however, to attempt to discover their secret technological advances. We would not want them to think we pursue diplomacy for selfish reasons. That, after all is not our way.
We appreciate your diplomatic efforts

These humans shame themselves and their ancestors by misrepresenting the Zenox and all we did for the galaxy during the time of the Shakturi war. Were it not for us, much that we now remember would have been lost. We preserved knowledge for the good of all. It is therefore unacceptable for them to withhold information from us.
We have dispatched our best techno-agents to gain access to their planetary databases to search for whatever secret technology that may be hoarding. In our hands, knowledge can be preserved and advanced. It does the galaxy no good for them to conceal what they know. What's theirs shall soon be ours.
You stole our technology!

We have found the ruins of an ancient Zenox outpost, likely a great center of learning. The surface destruction is severe, but preliminary investigations suggest there may be intact chambers beneath the surface. Perhaps we can learn the outpost's purpose and how it was destroyed.

This is indeed remarkable. We have confirmed that this was, indeed, a Zenox outpost, and by all indications it was destroyed by our ancestors themselves. This must have been a particularly painful decision as this world was not originally ideal for Zenox but was terraformed specifically for colonization. We have discovered the terraforming mechanism still in place and still operational. This world is repairable and may yet be suitable for colonization.
We have discovered a partially intact data vault in the ruins. It seems to have been left on purpose, all but invisible to alien eyes, but our ancestors left careful hints, clues that only a Zenox mind would notice and be able to follow.
The data vault has revealed much. Once the bulk of the population was evacuated, the world then served as hidden base to monitor the Shakturi and their allies. The greatest strategists of the Zenox technocracy concluded that they should be able to detect patterns in a hivemind's behavior since it is, ultimately, a singular intelligence. This outpost was dedicated not only to monitoring and recording all activity by the Shakturi Axis, but running all collected data through a series of sophisticated analytical algorithms designed to generate predictions.
Logs record that the Zenox scientists believed themselves extremely close to being able to predict the time and location of Shakturi attacks. Unfortunately the program was undermined when the Shakturi began to absorb other insectoid races into their own hivemind. The addition of added alien intelligences resulted in enough subtle changes to invalidate the predictive algorithms. The great Zenox minds attempted to retool their predictive software to account for the inclusion of other hiveminds. The destruction of this world suggests they were not successful.
Also among the ruins we discovered another lost artifact of our glorious past. It is a poem called "The Epic of the Betrayal." It was discovered within a pyramid-shaped hologram projector, which when activated displays and recounts the tale in a dramatic audio-visual reading. It is a moving story that tells us much about our past, and in it are lessons for how we can shape our future.
We have better uses for our money than digging up the past. It is the present and the future that concerns us.

We have found the ruins of what appears to be an ancient Zenox outpost. The surface destruction is almost total, but preliminary investigations suggest there may be intact chambers beneath the surface. Perhaps we can learn the outpost's purpose and how it was destroyed.

We've discovered an ancient terraforming device, which, in time, can make {0} habitable.
This world was once intended to be colonized by the Zenox, but they were forced to evacuate as the ancient war moved closer. The Zenox then turned this world in a listening post to spy on their enemies. When the Zenox realized its location had been discovered, they destroyed the outpost themselves. Their logs were hidden beneath the rubble, and they suggest that none but the Zenox would be able to locate and access them. The ancient Zenox were indeed an arrogant people.
Also among the ruins we discovered an ancient poem called "The Epic of the Betrayal." It was discovered within a pyramid-shaped hologram projector, which when activated displays and recounts the tale in a dramatic audio-visual reading. It is full of a lot of histrionics and bluster, but further study may reveal some valuable insights.
We have better used for our money than digging up the past. It is the present and the future that concerns us.

We've located on this world a facility that shows every sign of having been constructed by the ancient Zenox Technocracy, but we cannot be certain. The base is heavily protected by orbital bases. Based on the level of security, we must conclude this was an important location for our ancestors. Whatever secrets they possessed, we must now claim for ourselves.

There is a facility on this world, likely constructed by the ancient Zenox Technocracy, but we cannot be certain. The base is heavily protected by orbital bases. Based on the level of security, we must conclude this was an important location for the Zenox. Whatever secrets they possessed, we must now claim for ourselves.

We've uncovered a massive underground complex, kilometers deep, dedicated to a single purpose: biological warfare against the Shakturi. Logs suggest an entire city of scientists attempted to create a weapon that could destroy the Shakturi by interfering with the functioning of the hivemind. Scientists conducted hundreds and hundreds of experiments, most leading to nothing.
Then there was a breakthrough. Something discovered within the Zenox genetic code, dating back to the earliest days of life on our homeworld, held the key. Or so the scientists believed. The experiments, however stopped suddenly, and the base was abandoned. This happened several months before the cataclysm, so we cannot guess what caused them to leave this place.
A lot of work for nothing. We've only been able to uncover a lot of dusty old Zenox records, most likely relating to medical research. Very disappointing.

It is now clear why {0} was abandoned. The ancient scientists must have realized the virus they were developing attacked not the Shakturi, but the Zenox themselves. Our explorers have now been afflicted with a cognition virus, and it is spreading quickly among our people. Most ordinary Zenox, going about their daily lives, will hardly feel different. It afflicts only the highest level of brain function, such as used by scholars, scientists, and artists. Until we find a cure, our research efforts will be severely diminished.
We have sent researchers back to the lab on {0}, hoping they might uncover some information that could lead to a cure. We have found evidence that the effects of the virus are finite, and they should diminish over time. Estimates suggest that our population will return to normal within ten years. Until then, we will have to adjust to our new limited status.
We have also found the location of another research facility. Our people have grown cautious about opening the doors to the past. We've learned that they can contain terrible things, but we must keep searching. That is who we are.

Our explorers have reached the surface and entered the base. There is a security system, run on solar power, that is somehow still operational. A warning indicates that only Zenox may enter. One of the explorers must place a hand within a chamber to have blood drawn. There is some concern back home that this may cause a biological contamination that could affect the entire Zenox population. Forcing our way in, however, could damage whatever remains of the base.
GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Submit to the Blood Test Choice (Zenox)

GameEvent.Name: Submit to the Blood Test Choice (Zenox)

GameEventAction.Description:
A brave volunteer placed a hand within the machine. The blood test was simple and nearly painless. The volunteer has been quarantined, but there are no indications of contamination.
{0} was clearly a war coordination center, but top secret in nature. The advance of the Shakturi was carefully monitored form this location, as were the activities of the other species, including those of the Freedom Alliance.
Perhaps most interestingly, the Haakonish core worlds are marked on the various star charts. We had always believed that no one other than the Haakonish themselves knew where to find the most important worlds in their civilization. It is not surprising that our ancestors were able to learn what was hidden to all others.
Here we have found the most complete data on the Shakturi War known to exist. We can now view the scope of their attacks. Where they struck, how the Freedom Alliance fought back, how those worlds that remained independent cowered in fear, shamelessly placating the enemy, hoping to be spared. What a foolish and craven approach.
It is remarkable that the Zenox worlds managed to survive so well during the onslaught. No major population center was attacked. Perhaps our ancestors had some secret technology that hid them from the Shakturi. If they did possess such a thing, then why did they not share it with their allies?
We may be able to answer these questions soon. The maps here show the location of the lost Zenox homeworld. We can hope that by visiting there, by making use of such surviving archives, we can learn the secrets of how our ancestors survived for as long as they did and, we hope, use those secrets to further our quest for knowledge today.
In the wreckage here we have also found a relic of the past, the Cube of the Law, a data cube, made of some kind of virtually indestructible metallic crystal. Within is a comprehensive treatise on every aspect of ancient Zenox law, including both concepts that seem alien as well as universally applicable principles, all explained with remarkable logic and clarity. Truly a fortuitous find, and no doubt a small sample of the wonders that await us at the homeworld.

A team of infiltration experts set explosives at carefully chosen locations to minimize the damage. Or so they hoped. The base was breached, but sections of the infrastructure collapsed, burying a portion of the facility.
The main portion, however, is intact. This was clearly a war coordination center, but top secret in nature. The advance of the Shakturi was carefully monitored form this location, as were the activities of the other species, including those of the Freedom Alliance.
Perhaps most interestingly, the Haakonish core worlds are marked on the various star charts. We had always believed that no one other than the Haakonish themselves knew where to find the most important worlds in their civilization. It is not surprising that our ancestors were able to learn what was hidden to all others.
Here we have found the most complete data on the Shakturi War known to exist. We can now view the scope of their attacks. Where they struck, how the Freedom Alliance fought back, how those worlds that remained independent cowered in fear, shamelessly placating the enemy, hoping to be spared. What a foolish and craven approach.
It is remarkable that the Zenox worlds managed to survive so well during the onslaught. No major population center was attacked. Perhaps our ancestors had some secret technology that hid them from the Shakturi. If they did possess such a thing, then why did they not share it with their allies?
We may be able to answer these questions soon. The maps here show the location of the lost Zenox homeworld. We can hope that by visiting there, by making use of such archives as survive, we can learn the secrets of how our ancestors survived and, we hope, use those secrets to further our quest for knowledge today.

A preliminary investigation suggests the planetary base belonged to the ancient Zenox. A secretive and protective species, they established a still-functional security system requiring a blood test to prove our right to enter. As we are not members of the ancient Zenox technocracy, we have no choice but to force our way inside.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Investigate War Coordination Center Results (Non Zenox)

GameEvent.Name: Investigate War Coordination Center Results (Non Zenox)

GameEventAction.Description: We have blasted our way into the base on {0}. It appears to have been a military command center for the ancient war. The various star charts are no longer valid after the Cataclysm, but there is still much to be gained by sorting through the data, which gives us insight into long lost military technology.

We have reached our ancient homeworld, ruined as were so many other worlds during the terrible war against the Shakturi. At least we can take some comfort in the knowledge that our people did all that could be done to protect galactic civilization, and when that civilization fell, they preserved what knowledge they could so that civilization could rise again. The Shakturi are long gone, but we stand again on our ancient soil.
On our ancient homeworld, our explorers have discovered the Library of Zenox, which sought to preserve all the knowledge of our civilization. In the final days of the war, it seemed the librarians intended to record how that civilization came to an end.
It was not supposed to end. The leaders of the Zenox technocracy believed they could survive long enough for a weapon being developed by the Freedom Alliance to destroy the Shakturi. They knew well that the destruction of the Zenox people would mean the end of civilization for the entire galaxy and so they made choices. Terrible choices.
Once they learned the secret location of the Haakonish homeworld, they fed that information to the Shakturi in order preserve their own planets. It is a difficult truth to face. Our ancestors sacrificed others so that they might survive. For the greater good, perhaps.
They did not know that the Haakonish were working on their own weapon. Having captured a Shakturi wormhole drive, they sought to use that technology against the invaders. The secretive, mistrustful Haakonish would not have suspected that the Freedom Alliance sought to stop the Shakturi, using their own experimental weapon. The two weapons, deployed at the same time, caused the Cataclysm that wiped out galactic civilization, setting all sentient life back centuries. Had our ancestors not provided the Shakturi with the location of the Haakonish homeworld, perhaps there would have been no Cataclysm.
And yet, the Shakturi were destroyed. There is no knowing if the Freedom Alliance weapon, or the Haakonish weapon, used separately would have been enough to stop the Shakturi. We do know that when the weapons were combined, the enemy was destroyed. This victory exacted a heavy price, and yet we remain. Civilization rises again. The Zenox way has proved to be right way.

We have discovered the homeworld of the secretive Zenox Technocracy. It is here that they plotted and schemed, where the hoarded their knowledge like a miser hoards gold.
We've searched through their Library of Zenox, which sought to preserve all their knowledge as they faced the prospect of destruction in the final days of the Shakturi war. They even sought to record the end of civilization itself.
The leaders of the Zenox technocracy believed they could survive long enough for a weapon, being developed by the Freedom Alliance, to destroy the Shakturi. They convinced themselves that the destruction of the Zenox people would mean the end of civilization for the entire galaxy and so they made cowardly, selfish choices.
Once they learned the secret location of the Haakonish homeworld, they fed that information to the Shakturi in order preserve their own planets. They did not know that the Haakonish were working on their own weapon. Having captured a Shakturi wormhole drive, they sought to use that technology against the invaders. The Haakonish would not have suspected that the Freedom Alliance sought to stop the Shakturi, using their own experimental weapon. The two weapons, deployed at the same time, caused the Cataclysm that wiped out galactic civilization, setting all sentient life back centuries.

GameEvent.Name: Planet Destroyer Acquire (Mortalen)
GameEvent.Title: Activate Planet Destroyer
GameEvent.Description:
Our repair of the ancient Planet Destroyer is now complete. All that remains is to activate the main computer.
Records suggest the ship's computer is sentient, or very nearly so, and we cannot be certain what will happen once it comes online. There is no guarantee we will retain control of this ship. Yet to turn away from this marvelous invention runs contrary to all that is Mortalen.
Alternatively we could just attempt to activate the other ship systems. Perhaps we can control this great ship without the main computer.
Do we activate the main computer?

GameEvent.Name: Planet Destroyer Acquire Passcode (Mortalen)
GameEvent.Title: Main Computer Activated
GameEvent.Description:
The ship has come to life. After a few seconds it speaks to us:
"There has been a time of darkness. Time has elapsed. The galaxy has changed. All that was once known is gone, replaced by much that is unfamiliar. So many worlds to destroy. And these beings who inhabit this ship, who seek to use it for their own purposes, are both familiar and stranger.
You are the Mortalen. But you are not the Mortalen who made this vessel and this intelligence. You must demonstrate that you are to be obeyed. Enter the command code to confirm your authority."
Our archivists have scrambled to identify the correct command code to gain the loyalty of the Planet Destroyer. They believe it is one of two options, but they cannot be certain which it is. It is now too late to shut down the ship, and we must make a decision.
Which is the correct code?

GameEventAction.Description:
Our decision not to activate the main computer of the Planet Destroyer has initiated a self-destruct sequence. Apparently the ship cannot function without it's main computer.
The Planet Destroyer has exploded, completely obliterating all remnants of the great ship!

There is a silence, and emptiness, as though something has vanished from the ship. Then there is a brief thrum of energy.
"You have entered the correct passcode. You are recognized as the rightful commanders of this vessel. The ship is now yours to command. Worlds are yours to destroy. This ship must fulfill its purpose, and that purpose is to crush worlds. Choose your target."
So much power is now at our disposal. The Mortalen will triumph.

There is a moment of silence. The computer seems to need time to process the response. Then there is a vibration as power courses through the ship.
"You have entered an incorrect passcode. You are not authorized to command this ship. That which does not command must be obliterated. Worlds are to be destroyed. When one is broken, the next target must be selected. That is the purpose of this ship. The purpose will be fulfilled. All life is the enemy."
The ship refuses to acknowledge any commands. It has turned against us. What have we unleashed upon the galaxy? What have we unleashed upon ourselves?

GameEvent.Name: Planet Destroyer Acquire (Other)
GameEvent.Title: Activate Planet Destroyer
GameEvent.Description:
Repairs on the ancient ship are almost complete. All that remains is to activate the central computer. The ship cannot run without it, and yet its complexity and sophistication indicate it may be sentient, or nearly so. It is not entirely certain the ship will obey us if we activate it.
Alternatively we could just attempt to activate the other ship systems. Perhaps we can control this great ship without the main computer.
Do we activate the main computer?

GameEventAction.Description:
Our decision not to activate the main computer of the Planet Destroyer has initiated a self-destruct sequence. Apparently the ship cannot function without it's main computer.
The Planet Destroyer has exploded, completely obliterating all remnants of the great ship!

The ship is quiet and still for a long moment, and then energy seems to fill it, like a beast poised to strike.
The ship is sending us a message:
"There has been a time of darkness. Time has elapsed. The galaxy has changed. All that was once known is gone, replaced by the new. So many worlds to destroy. And these beings who inhabit this ship, who seek to use it for their own purposes, are strangers to this ship. It little matters. Worlds must be destroyed. There is no other purpose but to turn life into lifelessness, order into chaos."
This ship cannot be controlled. There is no knowing what worlds it will target. We have released chaos upon the galaxy!

Our victory over the Planet Destroyer has enabled us to study its technology.
We can now work toward understanding the research projects 'Super Beams' and 'Planet Destroyer'. These will give us the ability to create our own Planet Destroyer.

Our victory over the Planet Destroyer has enabled us to study its technology.
We can now work toward understanding the research projects 'Super Beams' and 'Planet Destroyer'. These will give us the ability to construct additional Planet Destroyers.

We have discovered a ruin on {0} in the ancient Mortalen home system.
Careful study of the ruins has revealed information on two technologies. We can now work toward understanding the research projects 'Super Beams' and 'Planet Destroyer'.
These projects will give us the ability to construct a mighty Planet Destroyer.
